a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes lattice_points :: "(int * int) set"
assumes h0 : "lattice_points = {(x, y). x \<in> \<int> \<and> y \<in> \<int>}"
and h1 : "card {p \<in> lattice_points. fst p powr 2 - snd p powr 2 = 17} = 4"
shows  "card {p \<in> lattice_points. fst p powr 2 - snd p powr 2 = 17} = 4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A lattice point in the $xy$-plane is a point both of whose coordinates are integers (not necessarily positive).  How many lattice points lie on the hyperbola $x^2-y^2=17$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 Applying the difference of squares factorization, we see that any such point satisfies $(x+y)(x-y)=17$. Both factors are integers. The only pairs of factors of $17$ are $(17,1)$ and $(-17,-1)$.
 Thus we have that the coordinates satisfy one of the following four systems: (i) $x+y=17$, $x-y=1$; (ii)  $x+y=-17$, $x-y=-1$; (iii) $x+y=1$, $x-y=17$; (iv) $x+y=-1$, $x-y=-17$.
 Solving each of these $4$ systems individually gives exactly one solution in each integers for each system.
 Thus there are $\boxed{4}$ lattice points on the hyperbola.
 *)

theorem
fixes lattice_points :: "(int * int) set"
assumes h0 : "lattice_points = {(x, y). x \<in> \<int> \<and> y \<in> \<int>}"
and h1 : "card {p \<in> lattice_points. fst p powr 2 - snd p powr 2 = 17} = 4"
shows  "card {p \<in> lattice_points. fst p powr 2 - snd p powr 2 = 17} = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many lattice points (x, y), where x and y are integers, satisfy the equation $x^2 - y^2 = 17$? The final answer is 4.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: int
assumes h0 : "x^2 - y^2 = 17"
shows  "card {(x, y) | x y. x^2 - y^2 = 17 \<and> (\<forall> m n. x = m \<and> y = n \<longrightarrow> (m \<in> Int) \<and> (n \<in> Int))} = 4"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A lattice point in the $xy$-plane is a point both of whose coordinates are integers (not necessarily positive).  How many lattice points lie on the hyperbola $x^2-y^2=17$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 Applying the difference of squares factorization, we see that any such point satisfies $(x+y)(x-y)=17$. Both factors are integers. The only pairs of factors of $17$ are $(17,1)$ and $(-17,-1)$.
 Thus we have that the coordinates satisfy one of the following four systems: (i) $x+y=17$, $x-y=1$; (ii)  $x+y=-17$, $x-y=-1$; (iii) $x+y=1$, $x-y=17$; (iv) $x+y=-1$, $x-y=-17$.
 Solving each of these $4$ systems individually gives exactly one solution in each integers for each system.
 Thus there are $\boxed{4}$ lattice points on the hyperbola.
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: int
assumes h0 : "x^2 - y^2 = 17"
shows  "card {(x, y) | x y. x^2 - y^2 = 17 \<and> (\<forall> m n. x = m \<and> y = n \<longrightarrow> (m \<in> Int) \<and> (n \<in> Int))} = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: How many ordered pairs of integers $(x, y)$ satisfy the equation $x^2 - y^2 = 17$? The total number of such pairs is 4.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes count_lattice_points :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. count_lattice_points x y = 
  (if (\<exists> m n. m \<in> \<int> \<and> n \<in> \<int> \<and> x = m powr 2 - n powr 2) then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "count_lattice_points x y = 1 \<longleftrightarrow> x powr 2 - y powr 2 = 17"
shows  "\<Sum>x\<in>{-1000..1000}. \<Sum>y\<in>{-1000..1000}. count_lattice_points x y = 4"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A lattice point in the $xy$-plane is a point both of whose coordinates are integers (not necessarily positive).  How many lattice points lie on the hyperbola $x^2-y^2=17$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 Applying the difference of squares factorization, we see that any such point satisfies $(x+y)(x-y)=17$. Both factors are integers. The only pairs of factors of $17$ are $(17,1)$ and $(-17,-1)$.
 Thus we have that the coordinates satisfy one of the following four systems: (i) $x+y=17$, $x-y=1$; (ii)  $x+y=-17$, $x-y=-1$; (iii) $x+y=1$, $x-y=17$; (iv) $x+y=-1$, $x-y=-17$.
 Solving each of these $4$ systems individually gives exactly one solution in each integers for each system.
 Thus there are $\boxed{4}$ lattice points on the hyperbola.
 *)

theorem
fixes count_lattice_points :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. count_lattice_points x y = 
  (if (\<exists> m n. m \<in> \<int> \<and> n \<in> \<int> \<and> x = m powr 2 - n powr 2) then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "count_lattice_points x y = 1 \<longleftrightarrow> x powr 2 - y powr 2 = 17"
shows  "\<Sum>x\<in>{-1000..1000}. \<Sum>y\<in>{-1000..1000}. count_lattice_points x y = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: How many lattice points $(x, y)$ in the range $-1000 \leq x, y \leq 1000$ satisfy the equation $x^2 - y^2 = 17$? The final answer is 4.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes count_lattice_points :: "((int \<times> int) set) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "count_lattice_points {p. (fst p)\<^sup>2 - (snd p)\<^sup>2 = 17} = 4"
shows  "count_lattice_points {p. (fst p)\<^sup>2 - (snd p)\<^sup>2 = 17} = 4"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A lattice point in the $xy$-plane is a point both of whose coordinates are integers (not necessarily positive).  How many lattice points lie on the hyperbola $x^2-y^2=17$? The final Answer is 4

 Applying the difference of squares factorization, we see that any such point satisfies $(x+y)(x-y)=17$. Both factors are integers. The only pairs of factors of $17$ are $(17,1)$ and $(-17,-1)$.
 Thus we have that the coordinates satisfy one of the following four systems: (i) $x+y=17$, $x-y=1$; (ii)  $x+y=-17$, $x-y=-1$; (iii) $x+y=1$, $x-y=17$; (iv) $x+y=-1$, $x-y=-17$.
 Solving each of these $4$ systems individually gives exactly one solution in each integers for each system.
 Thus there are $\boxed{4}$ lattice points on the hyperbola.
 *)

theorem
fixes count_lattice_points :: "((int \<times> int) set) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "count_lattice_points {p. (fst p)\<^sup>2 - (snd p)\<^sup>2 = 17} = 4"
shows  "count_lattice_points {p. (fst p)\<^sup>2 - (snd p)\<^sup>2 = 17} = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: How many lattice points (integer coordinates) are there such that the difference between the squares of the coordinates is equal to 17? The final answer is 4.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes count_lattice_points :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y. (x powr 2 - y powr 2 = 17) \<longrightarrow> (x, y) \<in> lattice_points"
and h1 : "count_lattice_points = (\<Sum>(x, y)\<in>lattice_points. 1)"
shows  "count_lattice_points = 4"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A lattice point in the $xy$-plane is a point both of whose coordinates are integers (not necessarily positive).  How many lattice points lie on the hyperbola $x^2-y^2=17$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 Applying the difference of squares factorization, we see that any such point satisfies $(x+y)(x-y)=17$. Both factors are integers. The only pairs of factors of $17$ are $(17,1)$ and $(-17,-1)$.
 Thus we have that the coordinates satisfy one of the following four systems: (i) $x+y=17$, $x-y=1$; (ii)  $x+y=-17$, $x-y=-1$; (iii) $x+y=1$, $x-y=17$; (iv) $x+y=-1$, $x-y=-17$.
 Solving each of these $4$ systems individually gives exactly one solution in each integers for each system.
 Thus there are $\boxed{4}$ lattice points on the hyperbola.
 *)

theorem
fixes count_lattice_points :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y. (x powr 2 - y powr 2 = 17) \<longrightarrow> (x, y) \<in> lattice_points"
and h1 : "count_lattice_points = (\<Sum>(x, y)\<in>lattice_points. 1)"
shows  "count_lattice_points = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: How many lattice points $(x, y)$ satisfy the equation $x^2 - y^2 = 17$? The final answer is 4.

natural problem: A lattice point in the $xy$-plane is a point both of whose coordinates are integers (not necessarily positive).  How many lattice points lie on the hyperbola $x^2-y^2=17$?
natural solution: Applying the difference of squares factorization, we see that any such point satisfies $(x+y)(x-y)=17$. Both factors are integers. The only pairs of factors of $17$ are $(17,1)$ and $(-17,-1)$.
Thus we have that the coordinates satisfy one of the following four systems: (i) $x+y=17$, $x-y=1$; (ii)  $x+y=-17$, $x-y=-1$; (iii) $x+y=1$, $x-y=17$; (iv) $x+y=-1$, $x-y=-17$.
Solving each of these $4$ systems individually gives exactly one solution in each integers for each system.
Thus there are $\boxed{4}$ lattice points on the hyperbola.
